message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s agitation and restlessness may be due to akathisia, a side effect of aripiprazole. Adding propranolol can help reduce symptoms of akathisia. Lithium is not indicated in this scenario. Increasing the aripiprazole dose can worsen akathisia. Stopping paroxetine can lead to withdrawal symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest akathisia, a known side-effect of antipsychotic medication. Propranolol is used to treat akathisia. Lithium is used to treat bipolar disorder, which is not the main issue here. Increasing the aripiprazole dose may worsen the symptoms. Stopping paroxetine may cause withdrawal symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest akathisia, a known side effect of antipsychotic medications. Propranolol can be used to treat akathisia by decreasing sympathetic nervous system activity. Adding lithium or increasing aripiprazole dose may not address the akathisia. Stopping paroxetine abruptly can cause withdrawal symptoms, and it may not be the cause of the akathisia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient likely has akathisia, a known side effect of antipsychotic medication. Propranolol can help alleviate the symptoms of akathisia. Adding lithium or increasing the aripiprazole dose may not address the specific side effect of akathisia, and stopping paroxetine may worsen the patient's depression symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting symptoms of akathisia, which is a common side effect of antipsychotic medications. Propranolol, a beta-blocker, can be used to treat akathisia. Adding lithium and increasing the aripiprazole dose are not appropriate for treating akathisia. Stopping paroxetine abruptly can lead to discontinuation syndrome, which can worsen the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest akathisia, a common side effect of antipsychotic medications. Propranolol is used to treat akathisia by blocking norepinephrine that can cause the symptoms. Lithium and aripiprazole are not indicated for treating akathisia. Some studies suggest that paroxetine can increase the risk of akathisia, but stopping it abruptly can cause withdrawal symptoms. It may be tapered down gradually under medical supervision.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has become agitated and restless despite compliance with medications, suggesting the presence of akathisia. Among the options, adding propranolol may help relieve symptoms of akathisia. Lithium is used to treat mania, and the patient does not have any symptoms of mania. Increasing the dose of aripiprazole may worsen the side effects. Stopping paroxetine suddenly may lead to discontinuation syndrome.

Adding propranolol can be helpful in managing the symptoms of akathisia. Adding lithium or increasing the dose of aripiprazole or stopping paroxetine is not indicated in this case.

Propranolol, a beta-blocker, can help alleviate the symptoms of akathisia. Adding lithium or increasing the dose of aripiprazole may not address the issue, and stopping paroxetine abruptly can cause withdrawal symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest akathisia, a common side effect of antipsychotic medications, which causes restlessness and inability to sit still. Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can help alleviate these symptoms. Adding lithium or increasing the dose of aripiprazole may not be helpful in treating akathisia, and stopping paroxetine may worsen the patient's depressive symptoms.
